description.plain:
On “Gucci Gang,” Lil Pump raps about women, money, drugs, jewelry, and high-end clothing—all recurring topics in Pump’s music.

The song became highly successful, debuting at #81 and peaking at #3 on the Billboard Hot 100, giving Lil Pump his first single to chart the Billboard Hot 100.

The music video was released October 23rd, 2017.

On March 17, 2018, a remix of the track appeared during the return episode of OVO Sound Radio, featuring the braggadocious Gucci-wearing rappers 21 Savage, Gucci Mane, Bad Bunny, J Balvin, Ozuna, and French Montana.

On “Gucci Gang,” Lil Pump raps about women, money, drugs, jewelry, and high-end clothing—all recurring topics in Pump’s music.

description.plain:
“D Rose” is a song about how Lil Pump has an expensive watch on his wrist and it makes him feel like basketball star Derrick Rose. D Rose is one of the richest players in the NBA as his net worth is over $70 million. He was the youngest player to win the NBA Most Valuable Player Award, in 2011.

http://imgur.com/c7XcVos

description.plain:
“ESSKEETIT” is an energetic instrumental that carries an extended bragging session. The track features bouncy synths and intermittent spurts of soft piano, accompanied by iconic Pump-style 808s.

The track is Lil Pump’s first self-produced track, originally previewed via Twitter on February 6th, 2018. On it, Lil Pump refers to his usual topics of designer clothing, drugs, expensive cars, and women. The title of the track, “esskeetit,” is a slurred pronunciation of the exclamation, “let’s get it.” It is frequently used in Pump’s music.

The track is set to appear on his upcoming sophomore project, Harvard Dropout, alongside “Designer.”

https://twitter.com/lilpump/status/961022649924182021

description.plain:
“Boss” a physical embodiment of Lil Pump at his prime. At the point of this track’s release, Pump was only just starting to blow up and this very well may be the song that helped him the most.
Produced by Diablo, the track has over 100 million plays on Spotify. The classic South Florida “trap” sound is depicted in this track with heavy bass and an aggressive sound.

Lil Pump decided to surprise his fans and release this track as an early Christmas gift.

description.plain:
“Drug Addicts” seems to entirely contradict Lil Pump’s early-year claims of being drug-free, but shortly after the song’s release, he reassured the public that he is still sober. The track, which was released alongside a music video on July 5, 2018, is formatted similarly to the rapper’s biggest hit, “Gucci Gang”, with a repetitive chorus and a single verse. Pump teased the song on May 5th, 2018 via Twitter and Instagram.

People went to Twitter to say that this song might be a response to rapper J Cole, because Cole supposedly dissed him on his 2018 song, “1985 (Intro to "The Fall Off”)“:

I hear your music and I know that rap’s changed
A bunch of folks would say that that’s a bad thing
‘Cause everything’s commercial and it’s pop now
Trap drums is the shit that’s hot now
See, I’ve been on a quest for the next wave
But never mind, that was just a segue
I must say, by your songs I’m unimpressed, hey

Some people thought this could also possibly be a response to the YouTuber Luna, who tweeted about Pump’s addiction:

Good choice and smart decision, def not winning in the sense he’s an addict at 17, I hope that’s his next smart decision is to get the fuck off percs and lean

Pump then responded through Direct Messages:

Stfu weird ass nigga ima slap u when I see u
Keep my name out yo mouth goofy

The timing was the main reason people assumed that it was a diss at Cole or Luna, as the snippet for the song dropped on May 5, 2018, a little over a week after the Luna beef, and a little over two weeks after Cole dropped 1985.

The music video features actor Charlie Sheen, who is well known for his drug addiction.

“Drug Addicts” is set to be released as a part of Lil Pump’s sophomore mixtape, Harvard Dropout.

description.plain:
“Butterfly Doors” is a single from Lil Pump’s upcoming sophomore studio album, Harverd Dropout.

On the song, Lil Pump boasts about his cars which have vertically-opening doors, a design feature seen on many high-end cars. Due to their resemblance to the winged insect, the doors are informally referred to as “butterfly doors”.

The song was released alongside the music video which features Pump in a club-lit garage with multiple “butterfly door” cars.

Pump first teased this track on his Twitter on December 16th, 2018:

https://twitter.com/lilpump/status/1074453325888679936

The video caused controversy because of the racial slur and gesture directed towards Asians. This even caused multiple Chinese rappers to release a diss track against him. He would later apologize for it in an Instagram post, saying:

I came here to tell you guys that I seen the whole thing going on on the internet and all that and I came here to tell you for my part that I’m sorry and I apologize for posting that. It was not my intention to hurt nobody or do none of that, deadass. I got Asian homies, you know, I fuck with everybody. I ain’t got nothing against nobody. It’s all love. I want everybody to have a merry Christmas and spread love and positivity.

For the official release of the song, the controversial lines were removed altogether from the music video, while “Ming” and “ching chong” are muted on the audio track.

description.plain: Crazy is the fourth track on Lil Pump’s self-titled debut mixtape and was also previewed on his instagram page 1 month before release. With this track, Lil Pump intends to provide insight into his unique lifestyle, and invites the listener to “go crazy”, or enjoy themselves in an energetic fashion, preferably while appreciating Lil Pump’s music.

description.plain:
The start of the “beef” between popular rapper Lil Pump aka Jetski and J. Cole.

This snippet comes as a response to the generation gap in rap music, where older rap fans criticise the appeal of the type of hip hop climbing the charts today.

Smokepurpp, Lil Pump’s accomplice, addressed Lil Pump’s message in an interview but also admitted it was some kind of joke:

We don’t sound like our OGs and when we’re the OGs, the younger people are not going to sound like us. […]
Nowadays everything is kind of a troll, so people know [our ‘fuck J. Cole’ tweets are] trolling, but if you don’t, we don’t care, Pump doesn’t care.

Cole eventually responded with his 2018 track,  “1985 (Intro to ‘The Fall Off’).”

description.plain:
On March 13, 2018, Lil Pump reportedly inked a new deal with Warner Bros. and four days later the Florida rapper debuted a remix of his breakthrough hit “Gucci Gang.”

Premiered on the return episode of OVO Sound Radio, the jam-packed guest list features 21 Savage, Gucci Mane, Bad Bunny, J Balvin, Ozuna, and French Montana.

description.plain:
In this song featuring Rich the Kid, an Atlanta rapper
formerly signed to Migos' Label Quality Control (now signed to Rich Forever, his own label), Lil Pump affirms that he is up next to make it big in the rap game.

While fellow South Florida rapper XXXTentacion was featured on the 2017 XXL Freshman Issue as the fan picked 10th member, Lil Pump was left out. This song may be a reference to Lil Pump being the next one after XXXTentacion to make it big out of the heep of South Florida rappers.

description.plain:
“What U Sayin'” (also called “What You Gotta Say” in some versions) is the first track on Lil Pump’s self-titled debut mixtape.

The song features Lil Pump’s best friend SmokePurpp but for some reason Purpp is not credited on the official Lil Pump tracklist.

The track is also produced by up and coming producers FadedBlackid and Trapphones.

description.plain:
“Movin'” is another banger by Lil Pump featuring his best friend SmokePurpp.

“Movin'” was removed from streaming services for unknown reasons. In an interview, Lil Pump said SoundCloud removed the song rather than him removing it himself. However, the song is still hosted on Worldstar Hip Hop’s YouTube channel.

Ronny J does the production for this track.

“At The Door” is the seventh track on Lil Pump’s self-titled mixtape.

description.plain:
Lil Pump teams up with Lil Uzi Vert to deliver “Multi Millionaire.” The track was released on October 5, 2018, and is the fourth single from Harverd Dropout.

This track marks the second collaboration between Pump and Uzi, following DestoDubb’s  “Bank Teller.”

The instrumental, produced by Danny Wolf, Hanzo, and Dilip, is Pump’s second collaboration with Wolf, following “Flex Like Ouu.”

The song was released on the one-year anniversary of Pump’s eponymous debut mixtape.

description.plain: The lyrical rap artist from South Florida whom is called Lil Pump made this amazing track to give his respect to the 44th president of the Untied States of America, Barack Hussein Obama. Lil Pump knew Obama very well as you can see in the single cover where Lil Pump and Barack Obama are shaking hands after having a wonderful conversation about their lives they live in this day in age. That conversation is the main inspiration behind this amazing song. The verse of this song is pretty much a summary of what Lil Pump and Barack Obama talked about during their loving conversation. Since Obama was about to end his 2nd term, Lil Pump made this song at his best ability to give his thanks to the 44th president of the United States of America, Barack Obama.

description.plain:
In this song, written by Lil Pump and featuring Smokepurpp a.k.a. Lil Water, he talks about people hating him and not liking them because they are ignorant, He also makes it sound as it does not bother him and is might actually not.

The beat features a sample from the theme song of popular Nickelodeon show, Spongebob Squarepants.

description.plain:
“Fasho Fasho” is a collaboration between Lil Pump and Offset that appears on Harverd Dropout. Pump first teased the song on his Instagram on August 13, 2018.

The song marks Pump’s first direct collaboration with Offset, but they previously collaborated on Lil Yachty’s “Baby Daddy.”

Pump and Smokepurpp have been outspoken about their love for Migos. They each have collaborated with Offset, and Pump has been pictured in the studio with Quavo.

description.plain:
Who Dat is a promotional single preceding Lil Pump’s debut self-titled mixtape, which comes only two days after Lil Pump’s collaboration with Smokepurpp.

Although it dropped three days before, the song will not be on his debut mixtape.

It dropped on October 3, 2017, along with a music video, although the video has been claimed by WMG.

description.plain:
On March 13, 2018, Lil Pump signed a new deal with Warner Bros. and over the next two weeks, debuted a mega-remix of his breakthrough hit “Gucci Gang” followed by this rendition of his hit-single “Designer” from late 2017.

This track features co-writers Blac Youngsta from South Memphis and Atlanta prodigy Rich The Kid who in 2016 started his own label, Rich Forever Music.

description.plain:
“Aight” is a single by Lil Pump which features his best friend Smokepurpp. It is hosted by Big E for Big E’s project Turn Me Up Big E 2.

The song dropped in between Smokepurpp’s DEADSTAR project and Lil Pump’s debut mixtape Lil Pump.

songs.lyrics:

Pop some more molly (ouu), drink some more lean
Damn I just missed my flight (ouu, goddamn)
Pick a hundred bands up for the next show (brrt)
I don't wanna fuck, bitch, I just want throat (no)
I didn't wanna tell you that your mama was a hoe (yeah)
Million dollars cash just layin' in the floor (Lil Pump)
All this ice on me drippin' (ouu, drip)
Kick a bitch out, she trippin' (yeah, ouu)
I'm too rich to listen (ouu, brrt)
And my pinky ring still glisten (yeah)
Told her don't lie-lie (ouu)
No, you can't spend the night (ouu, yeah)
Bitch do not ask me why (no, yeah)
Cut the check or bye (yeah)

[Chorus: Juice WRLD]
Okay, let's skate
Bad bitch finna come my way
Going 90 when I'm on the highway
Can't go high without the high, ayy
Everyday I wake up, smoke another gram, ayy
I don't give a fuck or another damn, ayy
I'm smoking the kush from the Hoover Dam, ayy
I'ma let these bitches know who I am
(I'ma let these bitches know who I am)

description.plain:
“Oh Yeah” marks the first collaboration between Lil Pump and Juice WRLD. It was released by the YouTube channel hhm on September 17, 2018.

It is an unofficial song and is actually a mashup of two different songs.

description.plain:
“King of The Trap” is a currently unreleased song by rapper Lil Pump.

In 2017, the song was registered to feature Young Dolph, however, it never saw an official release.

The song was auctioned by the secretive hacking group known as Music Mafia and has yet to see the light of day. Only a tagged snippet is available for listening.

description.plain: “Boppin'” seems to be an old Lil Pump track, with Pump’s sounding young in the song and having poor quality as well, although it was released in the summer of 2017. However, Pump and Diego Stax do not fail to deliver a hard banger over a Wii-themed beat.

body.plain: “Boppin'” seems to be an old Lil Pump track, with Pump’s sounding young in the song and having poor quality as well, although it was released in the summer of 2017. However, Pump and Diego Stax do not fail to deliver a hard banger over a Wii-themed beat.

Ayy man, we got rich lawyers (laughs)

description.plain:
“1 Choppa 2 Choppa” is the working title for an unreleased single by Lil Pump. As usual, Pump raps about his luxurious lifestyle and jewelry on the track.

A CDQ leak was posted on May 5th, 2018.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K5CkXQ1BO4M
